meta.title: Sacred Grounds - System Content
meta.subtitle: Streamlining e-commerce and inventory workflows for a gaming company
meta.teaser: Created systematic content for in-game shop interfaces, inventory management, and transaction flows. Developed scalable content patterns that maintained consistency across hundreds of items and purchase types.

project.summary: This case study demonstrates a digital workflow system designed to streamline trade skill interactions at Sacred Grounds Gaming's live-action role-playing events. The project focused on reducing player wait times, preventing rule violations through validation, and providing shopkeepers with clear, efficient navigation for processing mine openings. I chose this project because it showcases how thoughtful UX writing and process design can transform a manual, error-prone system into a fast, rule-compliant digital experience.

section.heading: Problem
section.body:
Sacred Grounds Gaming hosts live-action role-playing events where players interact with in-game shopkeepers to perform trade skills like mining, blacksmithing, and alchemy. The previous manual system created several critical problems:

  • Excessive wait times: Players spent 5+ minutes per transaction waiting for shopkeepers to manually calculate skill points, roll for results, and hand-write mine cards—creating long shop lines during time-limited events.
  • Error-prone processes: Manual calculations and card generation led to frequent mistakes: invalid mine cards, incorrect skill point costs, incompatible modifier combinations, and rule violations that disrupted gameplay.
  • Shopkeeper confusion: Without clear workflows, shopkeepers struggled to remember complex validation rules (event code formats, player number lengths, modifier incompatibilities) causing delays and inconsistent experiences.
  • Rule enforcement challenges: No systematic way to ensure mine cards, player cards, and generated items followed game rules, requiring post-event corrections and eroding player trust.

section.heading: Goals
section.body:
• Create an efficient digital system to open and harvest mines that complements game rules.
  • Limit the time players must spend in the shop during live events.
  • Provide clarity for shopkeepers to navigate the Shop app efficiently without memorizing complex rules.
  • Ensure rules are followed using Mine cards, Player cards, and properly generated items through automated validation.
  • Set clear validation rules and error handling to prevent mistakes before cards are generated.

section.heading: Flow
section.body:
Complete Workflow

The shopkeeper flow consists of four screens with built-in validation at each step:

  1. Screen 1: Event & Player Info — Input event code (7-16 alphanumeric) and player number (3-16 digits) with real-time validation
  2. Screen 2: Mining Skill & Modifiers — Select mining skill level (1-10), toggle modifiers, view live calculations for skill points cost, effective level, and mine opening time
  3. Screen 3: Rolling Results — Brief animation while the system generates mine type using probability tables
  4. Screen 4: Mine Card Result — Display generated mine card with mine number, type, skill required, uses remaining, and player/shopkeeper IDs

section.heading: Process documentation: Validation and error handling
section.body:
Input rules

The system checks all inputs to prevent invalid mine cards and enforce game rules.

Field Requirements Error message
Event code 7 to 16 alphanumeric characters Enter an event code that's 7 to 16 alphanumeric characters.
Player number 3 to 16 digits Enter a player number that's 3 to 16 digits.
Mining level Required. Select a value from 1 to 10. Select a mining skill level.
Modifiers Can't select both Fast Worker and Slow Worker Two or more of the toggled modifiers are incompatible. Check the modifiers and make adjustments to continue.
Error handling

When an input check fails, the system displays an error message below the field and blocks progression to the next screen. Correct all errors before you select Next.

Workflow steps

Screen 1: Event and player information

  1. Enter the event code and player number.
  2. Select Next.
  3. The system checks your input.
  4. If the input is correct, the system opens Screen 2.
    If the input has errors, the system displays error messages and stays on Screen 1.

Screen 2: Mining skill and modifiers

  1. Select a mining level from 1 to 10.
  2. Optionally, select modifiers.
  3. The system calculates skill point cost, effective level, and mine opening time.
  4. Select Open Mine.
  5. If your selections are correct, the system opens Screen 3.
    If your selections have errors, the system displays error messages and stays on Screen 2.

section.heading: Staff training material: Shopkeeper quick reference
section.body:
Quick reference for shopkeepers

Use this guide to complete the "Open a Mine" workflow efficiently and accurately.

Open a mine

  1. On the home screen, select Mining. (Other trade skills are unavailable.)
  2. On the mining selection screen, select Open a Mine. (Don't select Use a Mine.)
  3. On Screen 1, enter the event code and player number, and then select Next.
  4. On Screen 2, select a mining level from 1 to 10, select any modifiers, and then select Open Mine.
  5. On Screen 3, wait for the system to generate results.
  6. On Screen 4, show the generated mine card to the player, and then select Done.

Calculation formulas

Skill point cost

Skill Points = (Mining Level × 2) ± Modifiers

Effective level (range: 1 to 10)

  • Base level is the mining level the player selects.
  • Expert Miner adds 2 to the effective level (maximum of 10).
  • Novice Miner subtracts 1 from the effective level (minimum of 1).

Mine opening time

Fast Worker 10 minutes
No modifier 15 minutes
Slow Worker 20 minutes

Troubleshooting

Error: "Two or more of the toggled modifiers are incompatible. Check the modifiers and make adjustments to continue."

Solution: Ask the player to clear one of the modifiers.

Error: "Enter an event code that's 7 to 16 alphanumeric characters."

Solution: Verify that the event code doesn't contain special characters or spaces, and that it's 7 to 16 characters long.

Error: "Enter a player number that's 3 to 16 digits."

Solution: Verify that the player number contains only digits (not letters), and that it's 3 to 16 digits long.

Issue: The player doesn't know their player number.

Solution: Ask the player to check their player card or visit the registration desk.

Best practices
  • Ask players to have their player card ready before they come to the shop.
  • Verify that the event code is correct before you move to Screen 2.
  • Let the system calculate skill points automatically. You don't need to do the math manually.
  • If an error message appears, read it carefully and fix the issue in that specific field.

outcomes.outcome: Reduced average mine opening time from ~5 minutes to under 60 seconds through digital workflow automation
Created validation system preventing 100% of invalid mine cards and rule violations before generation
Decreased player shop wait times by 80% through efficient shopkeeper navigation and real-time calculations
Built reusable trade skill framework enabling expansion to Blacksmithing, Alchemy, and future skills
